Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the Philippine Department of Health has labeled the advisory as "fake" and has not issued any advisory on avoiding specific malls and hotels.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it is based on a misleading post on Facebook that has not been verified by any official source.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the information in the misleading post is accurate and reliable, without any evidence to support this assumption.
Exist alternative explanation: There is an alternative explanation that the list of malls and hotels to avoid may have been fabricated or spread as misinformation for unknown reasons.
Understate: The claim may understate the seriousness of the situation by focusing on specific locations to avoid, rather than emphasizing general precautions such as avoiding crowded places and mass gatherings.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by presenting conflicting information and failing to provide a clear and accurate source for the advisory.
Exaggerate: The claim may exaggerate the impact of the advisory by implying that it is an official government directive, when in fact it has been labeled as "fake" by the Department of Health.
